awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CRISPR-SERS system for rapid and ultrasensitive detection of foodborne bacterial pathogens
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacterial pathogens and their toxins are the most common causes of foodborne illnesses. Detecting pathogenic bacterial contaminants in complex matrices (e.g., fresh produce) is an essential step to ensure food safety. One of the major challenges for detecting those contaminants lies in the lack of rapid and ultrasensitive detection methods. This multidisciplinary project aims to develop innovative biosensors that can rapidly and accurately screen a large number of samples for pathogenic contaminants.  This project is integrated with outreach activities offered through the STEMette Summer Camp and Engineering High School Day to introduce K-12 students to the state-of-the-art biosensor technology. In addition, new course modules based on the results of this project are incorporated into existing undergraduate and graduate courses at both the University of Missouri and Rice University. 

This project includes three research objectives: (1) design a clustered, regularly interspaced, short palindromic repeats-associated system (CRISPR-Cas) to detect foodborne bacterial pathogens, (2) develop an ultrasensitive SERS system in a microfluidic device, and (3) integrate CRISPR with SERS in the microfluidic device for rapid, ultrasensitive, and selective detection of foodborne bacterial pathogens. This research discovers, contributes to, and supplements the fundamental understanding of essential principles for engineering CRISPR-based next-generation biosensors. By coupling CRISPR with SERS, this study also creates a new sensing mechanism that has the potential to achieve detection with single-copy sensitivity and single-base selectivity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our NSF-funded project aimed to develop an innovative CRISPR-SERS system for the rapid, ultrasensitive, and selective detection of foodborne bacterial pathogens. By combining CRISPR's single-base specificity with the ultrasensitive capabilities of Surface-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (SERS) in a microfluidic device, we sought to enable ultrasensitive pathogen detection, ultimately improving food safety and public health.

We successfully advanced CRISPR-based biosensing technologies. Specifically, we optimized CRISPR-Cas12a and Cas13a systems for nucleic acid detection. Through careful design and screening of crRNAs, we achieved enhanced specificity and reduced background noise in Cas12a-based assays, enabling more reliable detection of E. coli and L. innocua. Additionally, we engineered two Cas13a protein variants, RBD#3L and RBD#4L, demonstrating improved enzyme activities for viral RNA targets.  We integrated these systems with advanced biosensing platforms, including graphene field-effect transistors (gFETs) and electrochemical devices, achieving attomolar sensitivity levels without requiring amplification. These innovations mark a significant step forward in rapid, point-of-care diagnostic technologies. Our findings were published in four high-impact journal articles, including Nature Chemical Biology, ACS Sensors, two papers in Angewandte Chemie International Edition, and one US patent contributing to the scientific community's understanding of CRISPR-based detection systems.

Our project significantly advanced STEM education and outreach. Graduate and undergraduate students received hands-on training in molecular biology, CRISPR assay design, and data analysis, preparing them for careers in biotechnology and diagnostics. We also developed educational modules based on our findings and integrated them into undergraduate and graduate courses at Rice University, ensuring long-term educational benefits. Our CRISPR-SERS system holds great promise for improving food safety by enabling rapid and accurate detection of bacterial pathogens. This technology could also be extended to detect viral infections, enhancing public health resilience.

Our project has successfully demonstrated the potential of CRISPR-SERS technology as a powerful tool for pathogen detection, with far-reaching applications in food safety and public health. Our outcomes represent a significant contribution to both scientific knowledge and societal well-being, paving the way for future innovations in rapid diagnostic technologies.
